                            <a aria-label="2w    " class="app-aware-link update-components-actor__sub-description-link" data-test-app-aware-link="" href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/damienbenveniste?miniProfileUrn=urn%3Ali%3Afsd_profile%3AACoAAAT2LbsB3xS0kxwoZu8TsNvAXS5jonOKqiw" target="_self">
                             <span class="update-components-actor__sub-description t-12 t-normal t-black--light">
                              <span aria-hidden="true">
                               <!-- -->
                               2w 
                               <span class="white-space-pre">
                               </span>
                               <span>
                                <span>
                                 <li-icon aria-hidden="true" class="v-align-bottom" size="small" type="globe-americas">
                                  <svg class="mercado-match" data-supported-dps="16x16" fill="currentColor" focusable="false" height="16" viewbox="0 0 16 16" width="16" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
                                   <path d="M8 1a7 7 0 107 7 7 7 0 00-7-7zM3 8a5 5 0 011-3l.55.55A1.5 1.5 0 015 6.62v1.07a.75.75 0 00.22.53l.56.56a.75.75 0 00.53.22H7v.69a.75.75 0 00.22.53l.56.56a.75.75 0 01.22.53V13a5 5 0 01-5-5zm6.24 4.83l2-2.46a.75.75 0 00.09-.8l-.58-1.16A.76.76 0 0010 8H7v-.19a.51.51 0 01.28-.45l.38-.19a.74.74 0 01.68 0L9 7.5l.38-.7a1 1 0 00.12-.48v-.85a.78.78 0 01.21-.53l1.07-1.09a5 5 0 01-1.54 9z">
                                   </path>
                                  </svg>
                                 </li-icon>
                                </span>
                               </span>
                               <span class="white-space-pre">
                               </span>
                               <!-- -->
                               <!-- -->
                              </span>
                              <span class="visually-hidden">
                               <!-- -->
                               2w 
                               <span class="white-space-pre">
                               </span>
                              </span>
                             </span>
                            </a>
                           </div>
                          </div>
                          <button aria-label="Follow Damien Benveniste, PhD" aria-live="polite" class="follow update-components-actor__follow-button update-components-update-v2__follow-button artdeco-button artdeco-button--tertiary" type="button">
                           <svg aria-hidden="true" class="artdeco-button__icon" data-supported-dps="16x16" data-test-icon="add-small" height="16" role="none" viewbox="0 0 16 16" width="16" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
                            <!-- -->
                            <use height="16" href="#add-small" width="16">
                            </use>
                           </svg>
                           <span aria-hidden="true">
                            Follow
                           </span>
                          </button>
                          <!-- -->
                         </div>
                         <!-- -->
                         <!-- -->
                         <!-- -->
                         <!-- -->
                         <div class="feed-shared-update-v2__description-wrapper mr2" style="" tabindex="-1">
                          <div class="feed-shared-inline-show-more-text feed-shared-update-v2__description feed-shared-inline-show-more-text--minimal-padding" tabindex="-1">
                           <div class="update-components-text relative update-components-update-v2__commentary" dir="ltr">
                            <!-- -->
                            <span class="break-words">
                             <!-- -->
                             <span dir="ltr">
                              <!-- -->
                              Fine-tuning an LLM may not be as trivial as we may think! Depending on your data, it may lead to the model forgetting what it learned in the pretraining phase! You want to fine-tune it, but you also may want to retain its coding or chatting abilities. Because you most likely don't have the right benchmark data to validate it on different learning tasks, it might be difficult to understand the abilities it lost in the process!
                              <span class="white-space-pre">
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              Why would we want to fine-tune an LLM in the first place? There 2 main reasons! First, we may want to augment the model's data bank with private data, and second, we may want the model to specialize in specific learning tasks. A full fine-tuning takes time and money and generates a very large resulting model file. The typical way to go about it is to use Low-Rank Adaptaters (LoRA) to minimize the fine-tuning cost.
                              <span class="white-space-pre">
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              The idea is to replace within the model some of the large matrices with smaller ones for the gradient computation. Let's call W0 the weights of the pre-trained model for a specific layer matrix. After a gradient update W, the weights will be
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              W = W0 + W
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              and, if x is the input to that layer, the output of that layer will be
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              W . x = W0 . x + W . x
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              If we use the LLama2 with 70B parameters, we need to update all the parameters for each backward pass: computationally very expensive! Instead, with LoRA, we insert next to each layer matrix of the pre-trained model, 2 matrices A and B, such that the update is approximated by a lower rank decomposition:
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              W ~ B . A
                              <span class="white-space-pre">
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              The trick is that if W has dimensions (R, C), we can create B with dimensions (R, r) and A with dimensions (r, C) such that r &lt;&lt; R, C. For example if R = 10K, C = 20K and r = 4, then
                              <span class="white-space-pre">
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              W has R x C = 10K x 20K = 200M elements
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              B has R x r = 10K x 4 = 40K elements
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              and A has r x C= 20K x 4 = 80K elements
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              Therefore A and B combined have 120K elements which is 1666 times less elements than W. When we fine-tune, we only update the weights of those newly inserted matrices. The gradient matrices are much smaller and, therefore, require much less GPU memory space. Because the pre-trained weights are frozen, we don't need to compute the gradients for a vast majority of the parameters.
                              <span class="white-space-pre">
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              To gain even more space, we may want to quantize the float parameters into integers while applying LoRA (QLoRA). Now, the number of fine-tuned weights is just a fraction of the original model size, and we can more easily store those weights for each of the learning tasks for which we needed fine-tuning. When we need to deploy an inference server, we can use the original pre-trained model and combine it with the fine-tuned LoRA adapters for the specific learning task needed on that server.
                              <span class="white-space-pre">
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              That is worth a read:
                              <span class="white-space-pre">
                              </span>
                              <a class="app-aware-link" data-test-app-aware-link="" href="https://lnkd.in/gJ5dtZsE" target="_self">
                               <!-- -->
                               https://lnkd.in/gJ5dtZsE
                               <!-- -->
                              </a>
                             </span>
                            </span>
                           </div>
                           <button aria-label="see more, visually reveals content which is already detected by screen readers" class="feed-shared-inline-show-more-text__see-more-less-toggle see-more t-14 t-black--light t-normal hoverable-link-text" role="button" type="button">
                            <span>
                             see more
                            </span>
                           </button>
                           <!-- -->
                          </div>
                          <!-- -->
                          <!-- -->
                         </div>

                         <!-- -->
                         <div class="feed-shared-update-v2__description-wrapper mr2" style="" tabindex="-1">
                          <div class="feed-shared-inline-show-more-text feed-shared-update-v2__description feed-shared-inline-show-more-text--minimal-padding" tabindex="-1">
                           <div class="update-components-text relative update-components-update-v2__commentary" dir="ltr">
                            <!-- -->
                            <span class="break-words">
                             <!-- -->
                             <span dir="ltr">
                              <!-- -->
                              Fascinating. A new paper just showed you can jailbreak LLMs using simple ASCII art.
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              ArtPrompt is a new jailbreak attack which leverages the poor performance of LLMs in recognizing ASCII art to bypass safety measures and elicit undesired behaviors from LLMs.
                              <span class="white-space-pre">
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              It's based on the fact that five SOTA LLMs (GPT-3.5, GPT-4, Gemini, Claude, and Llama2) struggle to recognize prompts provided in the form of ASCII art.
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              | |
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              |  This can         |
                              <span class="white-space-pre">
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              |       hack AI      |
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              |                now.  |
                              <span class="white-space-pre">
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              | _ |
                              <span class="white-space-pre">
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              (\__/) ||
                              <span class="white-space-pre">
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              () ||
                              <span class="white-space-pre">
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              /  
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              Link in comments.
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              Are you technical? Check out
                              <span class="white-space-pre">
                              </span>

                              to get a weekly summary of the latest models, repos and papers in AI. Read by 170,000+ engineers and researchers.

                         <div class="feed-shared-update-v2__description-wrapper mr2" style="" tabindex="-1">
                          <div class="feed-shared-inline-show-more-text feed-shared-update-v2__description feed-shared-inline-show-more-text--minimal-padding" tabindex="-1">
                           <div class="update-components-text relative update-components-update-v2__commentary" dir="ltr">
                            <!-- -->
                            <span class="break-words">
                             <!-- -->
                             <span dir="ltr">
                              <!-- -->
                              Datasets for LLMs - A comprehensive overview (180+ pages) and analysis of LLM datasets.
                              <span class="white-space-pre">
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              The survey consolidates and categorizes the fundamental aspects of LLM datasets from 5 perspectives:
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              (1) Pre-training Corpora
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              (2) Instruction Fine-tuning Datasets
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              (3) Preference Datasets
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              (4) Evaluation Datasets
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              (5) Traditional Natural Language Processing (NLP) Datasets.
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              Additionally, a comprehensive review of the existing available dataset resources is also provided, including statistics from 444 datasets, covering 8 language categories and spanning 32 domains.
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              Paper in comments.
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              Are you technical? Check out
                              <span class="white-space-pre">
                              </span>
                              <a class="app-aware-link" data-test-app-aware-link="" href="https://AlphaSignal.ai" target="_self">
                               <!-- -->
                               https://AlphaSignal.ai
                               <!-- -->
                              </a>
                              <span class="white-space-pre">
                              </span>
                              to get a weekly summary of the latest models, repos and papers in AI. Read by 170,000+ engineers and researchers.

                             <button aria-label="Comment" class="artdeco-button artdeco-button--muted artdeco-button--4 artdeco-button--tertiary ember-view social-actions-button comment-button flex-wrap" data-finite-scroll-hotkey="c" id="ember338" role="button">

                               <!-- -->
                              </span>
                             </span>
                            </a>
                            <a class="ember-view update-components-actor__sub-description-button" href="https://newsletter.theaiedge.io/" id="ember300" rel="noopener noreferrer" tabindex="0" target="_blank">

                             </div>
                            </a>
                            <a aria-label="2w    " class="app-aware-link update-components-actor__sub-description-link" data-test-app-aware-link="" href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/damienbenveniste?miniProfileUrn=urn%3Ali%3Afsd_profile%3AACoAAAT2LbsB3xS0kxwoZu8TsNvAXS5jonOKqiw" target="_self">
                             <span class="update-components-actor__sub-description t-12 t-normal t-black--light">
                              <span aria-hidden="true">
                               <!-- -->
                               2w 
                               <span class="white-space-pre">
                               </span>
                               <span>
                                <span>
                                 <li-icon aria-hidden="true" class="v-align-bottom" size="small" type="globe-americas">
                                  <svg class="mercado-match" data-supported-dps="16x16" fill="currentColor" focusable="false" height="16" viewbox="0 0 16 16" width="16" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
                                   <path d="M8 1a7 7 0 107 7 7 7 0 00-7-7zM3 8a5 5 0 011-3l.55.55A1.5 1.5 0 015 6.62v1.07a.75.75 0 00.22.53l.56.56a.75.75 0 00.53.22H7v.69a.75.75 0 00.22.53l.56.56a.75.75 0 01.22.53V13a5 5 0 01-5-5zm6.24 4.83l2-2.46a.75.75 0 00.09-.8l-.58-1.16A.76.76 0 0010 8H7v-.19a.51.51 0 01.28-.45l.38-.19a.74.74 0 01.68 0L9 7.5l.38-.7a1 1 0 00.12-.48v-.85a.78.78 0 01.21-.53l1.07-1.09a5 5 0 01-1.54 9z">
                                   </path>
                                  </svg>
                                 </li-icon>
                                </span>
                               </span>
                               <span class="white-space-pre">
                               </span>
                               <!-- -->
                               <!-- -->
                              </span>
                              <span class="visually-hidden">
                               <!-- -->
                               2w 
                               <span class="white-space-pre">
                               </span>
                              </span>
                             </span>
                            </a>
                           </div>
                          </div>
                          <button aria-label="Follow Damien Benveniste, PhD" aria-live="polite" class="follow update-components-actor__follow-button update-components-update-v2__follow-button artdeco-button artdeco-button--tertiary" type="button">
                           <svg aria-hidden="true" class="artdeco-button__icon" data-supported-dps="16x16" data-test-icon="add-small" height="16" role="none" viewbox="0 0 16 16" width="16" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
                            <!-- -->
                            <use height="16" href="#add-small" width="16">
                            </use>
                           </svg>
                           <span aria-hidden="true">
                            Follow
                           </span>
                          </button>
                          <!-- -->
                         </div>
                         <!-- -->
                         <!-- -->
                         <!-- -->
                         <!-- -->
                         <div class="feed-shared-update-v2__description-wrapper mr2" style="" tabindex="-1">
                          <div class="feed-shared-inline-show-more-text feed-shared-update-v2__description feed-shared-inline-show-more-text--minimal-padding" tabindex="-1">
                           <div class="update-components-text relative update-components-update-v2__commentary" dir="ltr">
                            <!-- -->
                            <span class="break-words">
                             <!-- -->
                             <span dir="ltr">
                              <!-- -->
                              If your data is used to train a Machine Learning model, chances are that a Data Scientist, a Data Engineer, or an ML engineer is going to stumble upon it! I know, for example, that Walmart categorically refuses to use AWS as Amazon is their direct competitor and doesn't want to risk having their data fall into the wrong hands.
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              One solution to that data privacy problem could be to encrypt the data, but for typical encryption, that would mean that the whole training data needs to be encrypted. But if the Data Engineers own the key that encrypts the data, what would stop them from decrypting it when they receive new customer data? One way to go about it is to use Full Homomorphic Encryption (FHE).
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              FHE means that when you encrypt data, it preserves addition and multiplication operations. For example, if E is the encryption function, we have:
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              E(a + b) = E(a) + E(b) and E(a x b) = E(a) x E(b)
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              In practice, it means that FHE preserves any polynomial transformation of the data. If a computation involves a polynomial, computing and then encrypting gives the exact same result as encrypting and then computing. If we have a polynomial transformation P then
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              P(E( a )) = E(P( a ))
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              If D is the decryption function, we have D( E( a ) ) = a (the data is preserved after decryption). This means that
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              D(P( E( a ))) = D(E(P( a ))) = P(a)
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              That means that we can have computations with fully encrypted data completely equivalent to no encryption at all! If P is an ML model, that means that we can train a model with non-encrypted data, and infer on encrypted data. The model output will be encrypted as well and can be decrypted by the party that encrypted the data in the first place. This means that the model server host will never see raw customer data.
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              That is great, but that means that our ML model needs to be a polynomial transformation. Operations in neural networks like ReLU or Softmax contain MAX and EXP functions that are not polynomial. So, we need to modify the basic components of ML models if we want to use FHE. For example, this paper proposes precise polynomial approximations of NN components:
                              <span class="white-space-pre">
                              </span>
                              <a class="app-aware-link" data-test-app-aware-link="" href="https://lnkd.in/gscRFQ6h" target="_self">
                               <!-- -->
                               https://lnkd.in/gscRFQ6h
                               <!-- -->
                              </a>
                              <!-- -->
                              .
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              Another application for FHE is federated learning. Multiple models are learning on local machines with private data and are aggregated on a remote server. The remote server and the local machines can then sync their models after the aggregation. One problem with that is that we can always reverse engineer information about the private data from the trained model. Because the model aggregation on the remote server is typically a simple average, we can send the encrypted models to the aggregation server instead and decrypt the synched model locally. Unfortunately, that means that each client needs to share the same encryption and decryption keys, which are prone to attacks.
                              <!-- -->
                             </span>
                            </span>
                           </div>
                           <button aria-label="see more, visually reveals content which is already detected by screen readers" class="feed-shared-inline-show-more-text__see-more-less-toggle see-more t-14 t-black--light t-normal hoverable-link-text" role="button" type="button">
                            <span>
                             see more
                            </span>
                           </button>
                           <!-- -->
                          </div>
                          <!-- -->
                          <!-- -->
                         </div>
                         <div class="update-components-image update-components-image--single-image feed-shared-update-v2__content">
                          <div class="relative">
                           <div class="update-components-image__container" style="
        padding-top: 125%;">
                            <button class="update-components-image__image-link" type="button">
                             <span class="visually-hidden">
                              Activate to view larger image,
                             </span>
                             <div class="ivm-image-view-model">
                              <div class="ivm-view-attr__img-wrapper display-flex">

                              </div>
                             </div>
                            </button>
                            <!-- -->
                            <!-- -->
                           </div>

                           <!-- -->

                         </div>

                         <div class="feed-shared-update-v2__description-wrapper mr2" style="" tabindex="-1">
                          <div class="feed-shared-inline-show-more-text feed-shared-update-v2__description feed-shared-inline-show-more-text--minimal-padding" tabindex="-1">
                           <div class="update-components-text relative update-components-update-v2__commentary" dir="ltr">
                            <!-- -->
                            <span class="break-words">
                             <!-- -->
                             <span dir="ltr">
                              <!-- -->
                              Huge announcement. Anthropic just released the Claude 3 model family. Their Opus model outperforms GPT-4 on every benchmark.
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              Here's what you need to know:
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              - Three models: Haiku, Sonnet, Opus with varying intelligence.
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              - 200K token context window, expandable to 1M.
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              - Opus excels in MMLU, GPQA, GSM8K benchmarks.
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              - Sonnet twice as fast as predecessors
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              - Opus doubles accuracy, reduces wrong responses.
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              - Comparable vision capabilities to leading models
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              
                              <!-- -->
                              <span>
                               <br/>
                              </span>
                              <!-- -->
                              Are you technical? Check out
                              <span class="white-space-pre">
                              </span>
                              <a class="app-aware-link" data-test-app-aware-link="" href="https://AlphaSignal.ai" target="_self">
                               <!-- -->
                               https://AlphaSignal.ai
                               <!-- -->
                              </a>
                              <span class="white-space-pre">
                              </span>
                              to get a weekly summary of the latest models, repos and papers in AI. Read by 170,000+ engineers and researchers.
                              <!-- -->
                             </span>
                            </span>
                           </div>
                           <button aria-label="see more, visually reveals content which is already detected by screen readers" class="feed-shared-inline-show-more-text__see-more-less-toggle see-more t-14 t-black--light t-normal hoverable-link-text" role="button" type="button">
                            <span>
                             see more
                            </span>
                           </button>
